abstracts.cdata!:
This report is an environmental
            assessment summary for the Ports Rehabilitation Project of
            the State of Eritrea. The present project, Rehabilitation of
            berths 5 & 6 includes repair of a collapsed section of
            the existing quay, establishment of a new quay section with
            12 meters water depth, dredging and reclamation. The project
            further includes clearing of part of the port area and
            provision of new cargo handling equipment. The berth
            rehabilitation is assumed to lead to a slight increase in
            the water circulation within the port. The construction of
            berths will cause minor temporary impacts but will not cause
            lasting damage to the marine environment. The material to be
            dredged is suitable for reclamation purposes and free from
            contamination of heavy metals. The possibility of spillage
            during dredging and reclamation shall be minimized by the
            use of a suction dredger, installation of a sheet pile wall,
            and a survey and subsequent removal of all unexploded
            ordinances. Residents within port boundaries will be
            resettled into adequate alternative housing. The port will
            establish improved procedures for handling and storing
            hazardous and noxious cargo. Facilities are suggested to
            handle ship waste. An oil spill contingency plan will be
            drawn up and recovery equipment procured. Negative impacts
            includes: air, water quality, and oily wastes. (a) the main
            mitigation measures here are to carry out maintenance and
            repair work on vehicles and machines in dedicated areas with
            sealed surfaces and water treatment facilities, and to store
            fuels, lubricants and chemicals in safe places away from
            water; (b) use only adequate and well maintained
            construction and transportation equipment including diesel
            fuel of good quality. The reduction of particulate (soot)
            emitted by diesel engines is by far the most efficient
            measure for keeping the air pollution low; and  (c) oil is a
            common form of pollution that could cause a lot of damage in
            areas of noted sensitivity. As such, steps should be taken
            to ensure that it is not released into the sea or allowed to
            seep into the ground. These measures include the bunding of
            stored oils, the use of biodegradable oils and the provision
            of waste oil reception facilities (or oil banks). It is
            important that where water quality endangering liquids are
            handled for any purpose, the methods employed meet accepted
            standards for health, safety and the environment. A
            continuous regimen of maintenance and technical monitoring
            of processes is highly recommended to ensure that problems
            are identified early on, thus minimizing the risk of oil
            accidentally entering the sea or ground.
